q:
What is the output of the following C# code?

Code:

using System;
public class Demo
{
     int i; 
     public int j; 
     protected int k; 
     internal int m; 
     protected internal int n; 
     static int x; 
     public static int y;  
     static void Main()
     {
         Demo obj = new Demo ();
         obj.i =10; 
         obj.j =10;
         obj.m=10;
         obj.n=10;
         obj.k =10; 
         x = 10; 
         y = 10; 
         y = 13;
         Console.WriteLine(obj.i + obj.j + obj.k + obj.m + obj.n + x + y);
         
     }
}

What will be the output of the following Java code?
 

Code:

package hackerearth;
 
public class hack1
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        hack2 h = new hack2();
         
        System.out.println(h.H);
         
        h.hack_method();
    }
}
class hack2
{
    protected int H = 1;
     
    void hack_method()
    {
        System.out.println(H);
    }
}



Output:

  1. 1
1


     

  2. 0
1


     

  3. 1

a.option: The code gives a compilation error

q:
What will be the output of the following Java code?
 

Code:

public class Hackerearth 
{
    private static int hack;

    public Hackerearth() 
    {
        hack++;
    }

    protected static int hack_method() 
    {
        return hack;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) 
    {

       Hackerearth h1 = new Hackerearth();
       Hackerearth h2 = new Hackerearth();
       Hackerearth h3 = new Hackerearth();
       Hackerearth h4 = new Hackerearth();
       Hackerearth h5 = new Hackerearth();
       Hackerearth h6 = new Hackerearth();
       h6.hack++;
       System.out.println(hack_method());
    }
}


 

Output:

  1. 6


     

  2. 7


     

  3. 0

What will be the output of the following Java code?

Code:

package Hackerearth;
 
public class hackerearth
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        hack2 h = new hack2();
        System.out.println(h.hack_method1(0));
    }
}
public class hack1
{
    private int hack_method1(int hack)
    {
        return hack++;
    }
     
    public int hack_method2(int hack)
    {
      
        System.out.println(hack);
        return hack_method1(hack++);
    }
}
 

class hack2 extends hack1
{
    int hack_method1(int hack)
    {
        return hack_method2(++hack);
    }
}

 

Output:

  1.   
    0
1

     
  2.   
    1
1

     
  3.   
    1
2

     
  4.   
    2
3

What will be the output of the following Java code?

Code:

package hackerearth;
 
public class hack1
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        hack4 h = new hack4();
        h.hack_method();
    }
}
class hack2
{
    protected static String hack = "hello hackerearth";
}
 
class hack3 extends hack2
{
     
}
 
class hack4 extends hack3
{   
    static void hack_method()
    {    
        hack2.hack = "hello";
        System.out.println(hack);
    }
}

 

Output:

  1. hello hackerearth


     

  2. hello


     

  3. null

a.option: The code gives a compilation error

q:
Which of the following lines in the C# code snippet given below throws an error?

Code

public interface hack_Interface
{
    int hack_variable
    {
        
        protected get; // L1
        
    }
}

public class Hack : hack_Interface
{
    public int hack_variable
    {
        
        protected get // L2
        { 
            return 10; 
            
        }
        
        protected set // L3
        { 
            
        }
        
    }
}
In C++, which of the following options is not an access modifier?

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class Main {
	int a;int b=9;
	
	public int sum()
	{
	    	return a+b;
	}
	
	private int add()
	{
		return a+b;
	}

	int result()
	{
		return new Main().add();
	}
}

public class Examp3
{
	
	public static void main(String []aa)
	{
		Main e=new Main();
		System.out.println(e.sum()+e.result());
		
	}
}

In Java, which of these lines can cause an error in the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class B1
{
	public B1(){}
	
	private int a=10;  /**Line A**/
	protected int b=30;
	
	protected void sum()
	{
		 new B1().get();
	}
	private void  get()   /**Line B**/
	{
	   System.out.println(a+b);
	}
}

class B2 extends B1
{
	protected int c=10;
	
	protected void add()  
	{
		 sum();   /**Line C**/
	}
	
	}
public class Examp7 {
	public static void main(String []aa)
	{
	new B2().add();
	}
}

          e.sum3();  /**Line C**/
			 
 }
}

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class B1
{
	private int a=10;
	protected int b=30;
	public B1(int a,int b){
		
		this.a=a;this.b=b;
	}
	protected void sum(int a,int b)
	{
		 new B1(a,b).get();
	}
	private void  get()
	{
	   System.out.println(a+b);
	}
}

class B2 extends B1
{
	private B2(int a, int b) {
		super(a, b);
	}
	protected int c=10;
	
	protected void add()
	{
		 sum(10,20);
	}
	
	}
public class Examp7 {
	public static void main(String []aa)
	{
	new B2(2,3).add();
	}
}

In Java, which of these lines can cause an error in the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

abstract class MyClass
{  
	   private void disp1() /**Line A**/
      {
	     System.out.println("Parent class");
	  }
	  abstract public void disp2();
	  abstract  void disp3();
	  abstract protected void disp4();
}

class Program extends MyClass
{
	public void disp2() 
	   {
	       System.out.println("1");
	   }
	   void disp3() /**Line B**/
	   {
	       System.out.println("2");
	   }
	   public void disp4() /**Line C**/
	   {
	       System.out.println("3");
	   }
       public static void main(String args[])
       {
          Program obj = new Program();
       }
}

In Java, which of these lines can cause an error in the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

abstract class MyClass
{  
    private void disp1() /**Line A**/
    {
	     System.out.println("Parent class");
	}
	   abstract public void disp2();
	   abstract void disp3();
	   abstract protected void disp4();
}

class Program extends MyClass
{
	void disp2() /**Line B**/
	{
	    System.out.println("1");
	}
	void disp3() /**Line C**/
	{
	    System.out.println("2");
	}
	protected void disp4()  
	{
	    System.out.println("3");
	}
    public static void main(String args[])
    {
        Program obj = new Program();
    }
}

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

public class Examp8 
{
	 protected int a=10;
	 public int b=9;
	 int c=100;
	 protected Examp8(int a, int b)
	 {
		 this.a=a;
		 this.b=b;
		 c=99; 
     }
	 protected void add()
	 {
		 System.out.println(a+b+c);
	 }
}
class Program extends Examp8
{  
	public Examp8con(int a,int b)
    {
		super(a,b);
	}
    public static void main(String args[])
    {
        Program e=new Program(15,10);
		e.c=110;
        e.add();
    }
}

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class MyOuterClass 
{
	   protected int x= 1;
	   private String st="Number"; 
	   private void innerInstance()
	   {
	       MyInnerClass inner = new MyInnerClass();
	       inner. seeOuter();
	   }
	   public static void main(String args[])
       {
	       MyOuterClass obj = new MyOuterClass();
	       obj.innerInstance();
	   }
	   
	  private class MyInnerClass 
      {
	       private void seeOuter () 
           {
	    	   protected int x=2;
	          System.out.println(st+" "+x); 
	       }
	   } 
}

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

class A{
    public int x;
     private int y;

    void cal(int a, int b){
        x =  a + 1;
        y =  b;
    }        

}    

class Begin {
    public static void main(String []aa)
    {
        A obj = new A();   
        obj.cal(2, 3);
        System.out.println(obj.x + " " + obj.y);     
    }
}

q:
What is the output of the following Java 8 code?
Code:

public class _Hackerearth
{
  private static int $;
  public static void main(String[] main)
  {
    String s;
    System.out.print($);
    System.out.print(s);
  }
}

a.option: Compilation Error: Class name cannot start with an underscore (_)
Compilation Error: Local variables should be initialized before referencing

q: In C++, which of the following members of the class can be accessed by a friend function in which it is defined?

In Java, what is the output of the following code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

public class MyOuterClass
{  
       private int x= 1;
	   private String st="Number";
	   public void innerInstance()
	   {
	       MyInnerClass inner = new MyInnerClass();
	       inner. seeOuter();
	   }
       public static void main(String args[])
       {
           MyOuterClass obj = new MyOuterClass();
	       obj.innerInstance();
       }
       private class MyInnerClass
       {
	       private void seeOuter () 
           {
	          System.out.println(st+" "+x);
	       }
	   } 
}

import java.lang.*;

class A{

    protected int y;

        x =  a + 1;

        y =  b;

    }        

}    

class B {

    public static void main(String args[])

        A obj = new A();   

        obj.cal(2, 3);

        System.out.println(obj.x + " " + obj.y);

What is the output of the following Java code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class Add
{

   protected int addNumbers(int a, int b)
   {
	return a+b;
   }
}

class Test extends Add{
   public static void main(String []aa)
   {
	Test obj = new Test();
	System.out.println(obj.addNumbers(11, 22));
   }
}
Which of the following statements about access modifiers in Java is true?

a.option: The protected modifiers have more visibility or scope compared to private and lesser as compared to default modifiers.
The public modifiers have more visibility or scope compared to private and lesser as compared to protected modifiers.
The protected modifiers have more visibility or scope compared to private and lesser as compared to public modifiers.
The public modifiers have more visibility or scope compared to private and lesser as compared to default modifiers.
